text: I've been thinking some more and I worry that when I said, "what about a year?," that it's actually just not enough time.  Part of my reasoning with that, is that rethinking software construction is also probably deeply connected to rethinking hardware architecture.  It's a big task and I'm not sure how far you can get even in a year.  And stretching it to be multi-year makes it almost completely unviable for 99% of the types of researchers that would be a good match for it.

text: Jonathan's  “Burning Man for software revolutionaries”(I love the title, by the way) seems to me to be the next best thing.  It shouldn't be connected to any other conference or meetup, otherwise you'll just get the values of that group leaching into it.

elements.text: Jonathan's  “Burning Man for software revolutionaries”(I love the title, by the way) seems to me to be the next best thing.  It shouldn't be connected to any other conference or meetup, otherwise you'll just get the values of that group leaching into it.

text: Jonathan over on the general channel said it quite well: _The vibe at SL is highly accomplished hackers interested in advanced techniques._  If I were to choose one conference to go to, it would be SL, mainly because of the people going, not as much for the content of the sessions (for me).

elements.text: Jonathan over on the general channel said it quite well:
The vibe at SL is highly accomplished hackers interested in advanced techniques.
If I were to choose one conference to go to, it would be SL, mainly because of the people going, not as much for the content of the sessions (for me).

text: So let's hold a Future of Coding conference, perhaps the first in a series. During the face-to-face meetings that will occur during this conference, we can discuss more ambitious plans to make things happen as a group. To make it "more like Burning Man", we'd like the conference to be highly participatory and interactive. Ideally, each participant is in a position to show off something that they are working on.
